This variation on my releaux triangle was inspired by user elspeth.
You could describe this as a triangle that rolls inside a square inside a triangle that rolls inside a square.

I have put ears on the outermost square to try to reduce warping, but this is so big and flat warping is probably inevitable.  I think the ears (there to reduce warping) may throw the size over the limit for the cupcake...I think the raft goes over the screws.  On request I can include a version without ears, or you can comment the line out in the scad file.
As with the previous thing, the resultant objects should not actually touch except for strings and raft.  The gap is a 45 degree slot, which should be easy to pass a knife thorough.  However, the tolerances may be tight, I tried to manually center the inner triangle a bit to help this.
Also, as with the previous thing, I suspect that this may tickle bugs in skeinforge. As with the parent part, skeinforge 35 and previous are known to not slice this object correctly, skipping some or all of the solid layers on some parts.  (See Disrespective's picture.)  Skeinforge 40 appears to overfill one layer.

title: Improved LED simulation Green Cape Lighthouse model

description.text: Thanks to the amazing project developed by gwpoulos, I adapted his idea to my Green Cape Lighthouse model with excellent results: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VvJgFoeqf18&feature=youtu.be The 3D printed housing pieces for the LEDs were redesigned to fit my model and adapted to the LED strip available where I live. Also, a Deek Robot Arduino Pro Mini clone was used (I couldn't find the original), and it worked fine. I used a 5V external regulator as suggested in the original project for long term operation.

Pieces were printed in PLA, normal settings with no support. Two rings are needed, one for the top and other for the bottom.  
To adapt this modification to the existing model of Green Cape Lighthouse, you have to print the new_optics 1, 2 and 3 pieces to fit them in top of the existing balcony.  I included two new pieces; new_optics 4 and 5 if you prefer to assemble the window frames instead of printing them as one piece.  
Additionally, if you want the function buttons of the electronic circuit to be reachable from the outside of the model, print the new_base piece which was also modified to save some printing material but is a little bit harder to align with the rest of the body pieces.  
The rest of the original lighthouse model pieces (body 1, 2 and 3; balcony 1 and 2; dome and accesories) can be used and had no changes.

A watch housing to hold a binary watch circuit. This watch shows the hour and minutes by flashing two LEDs in sequence to represent two 4-bit binary numbers. The left LED represents the 0's and the right LED represents the 1's. The first set of flashes is the hour, the second set of flashes is the minute. It has three pieces that pressure fit together very nicely. The body and the face pieces have an oval so that you can align the parts up evenly when the two pieces are together. The face piece has two tabs to help hold the circuit board in place. It also has pin holes to add your own strap. https://youtu.be/8e5y9DavaEo UPDATE! I've added a circuit board template. Print the template and trace the inside onto the circuit board. Then cut/sand just to the line and then fine tune to fit.

I built the circuit using an AtTiny85, 2 resistors, 2 Leds, a momentary push button and a cr2032 battery holder. The I designed the circuit layout so I din't need any wires, all connections are made with solder bridges or using the leads of the components. The sketch flashed onto the AtTiny comes from othermachine's "nerd watch" project on Instructables. I used most of the same code, line for line with just a few changes I made for my watch. Get their sketch files here: http://www.instructables.com/files/orig/FYH/T5PV/I504WRDF/FYHT5PVI504WRDF.zip It has three pieces that pressure fit together very nicely. The body and the face pieces have an oval so that you can align the parts up evenly when the two pieces are together. The face piece has two little tabs on the inside to hold the circuit board in place. It also has pin holes to add your own strap. This watch shows the hour and minutes by flashing two LEDs in sequence to represent two 4-bit binary numbers. The left LED represents the 0's and the right LED represents the 1's. The first set of flashes is the hour, the second set of flashes is the minute. The circuit board should be about a 37mm diameter circle ( I use a scroll saw to rough cut then a bench sander to sand to shape) and the components should be positioned in a window 28.5mm wide by 22.5mm high in the middle of the board. I put all the components on the top with only the batter holder on the bottom. This is a little tricky but can be done.

author: Andrew_Ryan

description.text:
Base off the Lun-class ekranoplan ship. The whole idea of the ekranoplan ship was to have a ship that move incredibly fast, and to do this Russian engineers devised this concept of a ship that can seamlessly hover above the water to reduce water resistance. The ship of this caliber was produced and prototyped back during the Cold War and its secrets of how it can hover above the water were kept hidden by the Russians. However, later on this was discovered to be the ground effect. The Russian prototype was nicknamed the Caspian Sea Monster during the Cold War. This is something I made for fun a long time ago. It isn't anything special (or functional)
This video demonstrates the ground effect pretty nicely: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_iqqHAWJq_0

comments.text: Ummm secret? I would doubt your source. It's a simple WIGE flying boat. That's Wing In Ground Effect. It's a widely known principal.

title: Gaelic Box, with double hinged lid, held close by a latch that is a novel all-in-one "impossible" turning joint

description.text:
Designed for Instructables 3-d printing contest, discussing ways to improve our 3d prints. The front and top stl file is the Lid which is in 2 parts and hinged. I use large paperclips to make the hinge. Its a tight fit and the space between the hinge pins, as well as the through holes for the hinge pin, require careful cleanup, if the pin holes are too tight, heat up a bent paperclip with a cigarette lighter to help clean the holes. Note the Top lid is printed upside down to make a cleaner wave decoration. The Box stl file is the main box. It includes a novel, original, all-in-one hinge joint which rotates and makes the latch. The latch goes through the wall and can't be pushed or pulled through the wall without destroying the box. Support is only on either side of the wall. CAREFUL cleanup is needed to work this free so it rotates freely. This joint makes the box TOO COMPLEX to be sliced with slic3r, I used Cura with good results. Here is a little vid showing the box in use:
https://youtu.be/WpKsjL0TdP8

The Box body is too complex to slice with slic3r, I used Cura.  
Designed using Blender, units are mm.  
has been successfully printed in PLA and woodfill PLA

Since I had been messing with a case ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8860 ), I decided to try to mash them together into a little travel Tic-Tac-Toe game. There is a little video of it building here:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nRKHwylv1Ms This is an original work, but is similar to:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7614
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8881

The ZIP includes the OpenSCAD source. The OpenSCAD source is not an example of good programming. Just hacked together for fun.
There is a logo on the bottom, you can delete that or replace it with one you like.
1) Print.
2) You might need to sand or tweak the lid slightly. With my printer it goes together right off the build platform, but I had to tweak quite a bit to make that happen.
3) Try to remember when you thought little boxes with parts in them were cool.
4) After you give up, let a kid have it, they still think little boxes with parts in them are magic.
5) Wonder if the little pieces will break the vacuum as they rattle through it.

description.text: This is a wheel I designed for a Tower Pro MG995 round servo horn or a 21mm diameter servo horn.  The wheel is 3" in diameter and .5" wide.  For added traction, two rubber bands can be put on the edge of the wheel.  The wheel features easy access to the servo horn mounting screw for easy removal of the wheel and horn at the same time.  I designed the part in inches so if you have 3D printer software that uses mm you must scale the object by 25.4 to get it to actual size, or 2.54 if it uses cm. This is calculated by the conversion from inches to millimeters. NOTE: I printed this in PLA, if you print in ABS the part will shrink some, making it hard to fit the servo horn.  If you print in ABS you might need to scale the object slightly larger than 25.4.

Any round 21mm servo horn should be compatible.  Be sure to scale the wheel by either 2.54 or 25.4 if your printer software uses cm or mm. I used a Prusa i3 and repetier host and had to scale it by 25.4.  To assemble the wheel simply fasten the servo horn to the wheel with the appropriate sized bolts and nuts (I just used some spare ones I had laying around), then you can screw the entire wheel on with the screw that came with the servo.  If you want more traction you can add two thick rubber bands to the outside edge of the wheel - the wheel is just the right size for the tension to keep the rubber bands in place.

title: Printrbot Plus Metal RPi Camera Bed Mount

description.text:
Here is a PrintrBot Plus mount for my old Raspberry Pi camera holder for the Simple Metal. This works great on my Plus Metal (Model 1504) with heated bed, though I haven't tested it on earlier models. Please let me know if there is a problem. There is almost zero clearance beneath the bed, so the old design didn't work. Instead, the mount now clamps around the side using two parts that screw together using the included bolt. The part can only be mounted on the right side of the printer bed. It clamps onto a rail underneath the platform, and there is a rail guide on the left that would interfere with the mount. It does not mount to the heated part of the build platform. I recommend you print the bolt separately with 100% infill. Video: https://youtu.be/BSsBb5mOl48
Video: https://youtu.be/VDzU88u5-_U P.S. I switched to an alternative RPi fisheye camera months ago. You can use the following case with this mount if you have the same camera. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:670483

I recommend you print the bolt separately with 100% infill. You'll also probably need an especially long camera cable. I found the 18" one was just barely enough to stretch to a RPi mounted to the lower side of the Printrbot Plus. Camera cables are available here:
https://www.adafruit.com/products/1648

author: kapitimartin

title: Makerfront i3PRO threaded rod bushing for frame top

description.text: The threaded rods on my Makerfront i3pro are warped and not so easily straightened. The rods often contact the metal frame and make a horrible vibrating sound. One day I'll get around to replacing the rods, but until then, a couple of these plastic bushings reduces the problem quite tolerably. The bushings fit snugly in the threaded rod clearance holes on the top of the i3pro. The M5 threaded rods fit through easily but will make contact with the inside diameter if they're warped. To prevent the z-feed from popping the bushing out then just snug down a zip tie in the channel around the cylinder once it's in place.

This top and base is designed to fit the Tint Tubes used by a number of the Christmas Light displays in Australia. The 78mm ID tubes form an interesting and cheap light when illuminated from inside with LED or Pixel strip.   
This cap is designed to seal the top and bottom of the tube, The top cap is designed to stop weather, dust and dirt from getting in the tube, and the bottom has a slot to allow cable entry into the tubes, while still limiting the entry of grass and bugs. At only 5mm thick, they are not a large bulky item, and are relatively quick and cheap to print.  
Best printed with 2 wall thicknesses, 15% infill and a color and material that suits your needs. I used white ABS for my tubes, and this will also let some light illuminate them from the tint tube, thus forming a part of the display. While they are a press fit, you may like to add some silicone to ensure they don't fall off

I made this to hold a set of 6 3/8" drive allen wrench sockets.  Commercially available socket organizers had way too many slots for this six piece set.  
Note: I've updated the design to include a customizable version.

Print flat side down.  no support.  For me, a raft helps, but is not necessary.  I recommend PLA but any material should work.  the sockets should have a slight clearance fit making them easy to insert and remove.

comments.text: dude, as a mechanic, this is just awesome! While there are MANY socket organizers out there, often times the organizers have too many slots, or don't stand up on their own, or either have no numbering or incorrect numbering for the sockets. This takes care of all those problems, PLUS, I can make these any color I want! I do have a few suggestions though. One being the ability to use letters for certain sockets like Torx (eg T6) and the ability to do fractional sizes (eg 3/16). Another suggestion would be to be able to mix drive sizes on the same rail. Sometimes, a set of sockets may be 1/4" drive on the smaller sizes and move up to 3/8" drive. And one last one but it might be a stretch, would be better control of the spacing between the sockets. What I mean is the ability to set the spacing between each socket since an 8mm socket needs much less room than a 21mm socket and if you space everything for a 21mm socket, then there will be huge gaps around that 8mm socket and lots of wasted space. Anyways, just a few suggestions that would push this over the top. Thanks again for this excellent design and keep up the great work!
comments.author: caminiti45

comments.text: This is really cool, and love the fact it's adjustable in Customizer.  Can you include a little lip in front of the sockets that has customizable editable text.  Then I could have it printed to say, "XYZ's Sockets", or whatever else I wanted.

comments.text: Done.  :)

comments.text: Can you be more specific?  I can't fix it or help you otherwise.
comments.author: tminus10

comments.text: That's fair. I made it for a coworker, so I can't follow up right now until the weekday. But from the looks of it, it was a very loose fit and wouldn't stay unless wrapped with a few layers of tape. I'll try bringing some digital calipers to work and measure the clearances when I get the chance.
comments.author: cnt

comments.text: Ah.  If you check the customizer I have a 'Clearance' option.  For a perfect printer setting that to 0 gives you a perfect fit.  Positive numbers (in mm) give you a clearance ("loose") fit and negative numbers give you an interference ("friction") fit.  I set the default to 0.3mm so that I could lay the organizer in my drawer and just lift sockets out.  If you want them to fit it tight set the clearance option to 0.0 or maybe -0.1.  It depends on your material and printer but most printers effectively dilate parts due to imperfect layers.

title: Z-Endstop Reprap Neo
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
There is a revision of this Thing. The advantage is, you can adjust it from the front side. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:987256 Inductiv endstop for German Reaprap Neo.
This part is an replacment for the original endstop. There is no need for any software update or additional hardware. All you need is:
  • an Induktiv Sensor ( PNP Normaly open M8)
  • a 3-pin Connector to connect it to the printrboard
  • 2 Screws M3
  • 2 nuts M3
  • Open the back side of the Printer
  • Unscrew the original endstop
  • Assemble this part with the inductive sensor
  • Mount the assembly at the hohles
  • Shorten the wire, crimp the Connector and connect it.
  • Test it
  • Close all an be happy!

comments.text:
OK, so what you're recommending for the replacement for this is an 8mm, PNP normally open Inductive Sensor, correct? Do you have a source for this? When I search for this, the sensor is giving me a little sticker shock and want to be sure.
Thanks.
comments.author: mikethebomber

comments.text:
There is a revision online right now on http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:987256 .
The advantage is, you can adjust it from the front side. The disadvantage is, your printing setting must be good to print it correct. The nuts should slip in. The one on the pictures was printed by my Neo.
comments.author: mikethebomber

comments.text: What does this do for the Neo as an upgrade?  Do you get a slightly higher z build volume?
comments.author: mikethebomber

comments.text:
You won't get additionally volume, you will get a more reliable Printer, because the z-endstop is more accurate. My original endstop had a tolerance of 0.07 to 0.08 mm. With this upgrade you will get a tolerance under 0.02mm, probably 0.01mm.
The high of the first Layer varies by this tolerance with every homing of the z-axis. If you have to adjust the bed at the beginning of every print, because the high of the first layer is not correct. This upgrade is great for you.
comments.author: mikethebomber

Up late at night and decided I'd use some of my time to design a little kayak! Me personally, I love to kayak, breaking those glassy waters of a river is INSPIRING! Print is made into TWO files. One for paddles, the other for the kayak itself. Multi-color maybe???????? ;) MAKEITFLOAT: Length (bow to stern):175mm / 6.88976Inches
Width (at waist): 40mm / 1.5748Inches Weight:21.4g
Maximum carrying weight +30g
Total weight when maxed 51.4g (weight of paddle .5g) The kayak can carry 1.4 times its own weight. Maximum Capacity: 5 Quarters (1.25) USD)
OR
6 Nickels (0.35 USD)
OR
11 Pennies (0.11 USD)
OR
13 Dimes (1.30 USD) If the weight of the object is < the buoyant force the object will float
If the weight of the object is > the buoyant force the object will sink
If the weight of the object is = the buoyant force the object will experience equilibrium The deeper an object is submerged, the greater the pressure is. Which means that the pressure on the bottom of the object, in this case a kayak, is greater than the pressure above the surface of the water. In short, pushing the boat up towards the surface. According to Archimedes’ Principle, the buoyant force is equal to the weight of the fluid displaced by an object, once again in our case, the kayak. The density of the PLA (polylactic acid) is 1,210–1,430 kg/m3
The density of Water (H2O) is 999.97 kg/m³ This means that a SOLID centimeter cube of PLA would SINK in a bowl of water. So in order to counteract that, Need to make the density of the BOAT lower than the density of the water. Of course the USA sticker helps it float too! GREATNESS RISES!

First, prepare the "Kayak.stl" file.
Second, prepare the "Paddles.stl" file.
Finally, print & enjoy! Maybe have the paddles one color and the kayak another?? Ideas man.. Ideas.

author: bookmake

description.text:
A simple throwing dart. Designed to spin while in mid air with the counter-clockwise aerofoils. Heavy towards the front for balance.  
Also with notch for a sting Juuuuuust in case you get to makin' a bow too.

If you're clumsy like me, you'll notice how hard it is to keep the bowden tube straight while you're trying to thread an M4 nut into it.  
This is a tool that keeps your bowden tube aligned with the nut for threading. It also features a hole at the bottom for re-drilling the bowden tube after the nut has squeezed the hole smaller.

• Print.
  • Stick nut into hexagonal recess.
  • Snap the pieces together.
  • Gripping the PTFE tube with your hand, push it in from the top and twist it into the nut until you notice the Bowden tube pushing the pieces of the jig apart.
  • With the jig still assembled, use a drill bit to re-drill the hole of the PTFE tube which should have shrunk a bit from the compression caused by threading.

comments.text: This is a fixture not a "jig".
comments.author: Phibsboro

comments.text: Hmmmm. This is enlightening and confusing at the same time. I just read both the wikipedia articles for jig and fixture, but I'm having difficulty fitting this into the context. Here, the tool would be the nut, right? Or would both the nut and the Bowden tube be the work? I designed this piece to hold the nut steady and steer the Bowden tube into the nut as you thread it, after which you remove this thing, leaving the nut fully threaded into the Bowden tube. If the nut was counted as part of the work, would this thing be a tool (like a specialized spanner) rather than a jig/fixture?
comments.author: Phibsboro

comments.text: In this instance both would be the work.
comments.author: hyperair

comments.text: Hmm, I'm getting a clearer picture now, but am still unable to fit that into the context of this thing. It doesn't seem to be either jig or fixture, so I'll just call it a Bowden threading tool or something.

author: robkar

description.text: This filament spool mount is specific for the BFB 1kg filament spools. The spool wheels fit into the spool's hub where the hub's inside diameter is 72mm to 76mm and the wheel's lip diameter is 82mm to prevent it from going into the spool's hub. The wooden dowel rods used for the framework are 10mm diameter. They might not be sufficient for 2 x 2.3kg filament spools but seem to hold the 2 x 1kg spools fine. I'm sure that with some gussting / bracing even these 10mm dowels should be able to handle 2 x 2.3kg filament spools. That is defintely something I will look into. [EDIT] - 2011/06/03 - I have uploaded new parts with the holes slightly opened up to allow for less work to make the dowel rods fit.

You will probably have to open up the holes a little to fit your 10mm dowels. The spool wheels should rotate freely while everything else must be a snug fit. All dowels must go 30mm deep into the connectors For 1 filament spool:
Cut 2 pieces 10mm wooden dowel of 284mm each.
Cut 3 pieces 10mm wooden dowel of 125mm each.
Cut 1 piece 10mm wooden dowel of 157mm.
Print 2 of 3 way connector.stl
Print 2 of spool axle holder.stl
Print 2 of spool wheel.stl
Print 4 of spool frame clamps.stl
Mount the 284mm dowels to the 8mm rear upper and lower cross bars with the spool frame clamps and adjust them with a gap of 125mm between the dowels.
Fit a 125mm dowel between the 3 way connectors so that one end of the connectors points toward the front of the machine and the other end down.
Fit this unit over the two uprights.
Fit a 125mm dowel into each of the connectors facing forward.
Fit a spool axle holder over the end of each of these two dowels with the open ends facing up.
Place a spool wheel into each side of your BFB filament spool and insert the 157mm dowel through their centers and push this assembly into the open ends of the spool axle holders. For 2 filament spool:
Cut 3 pieces 10mm wooden dowel of 284mm each.
Cut 5 pieces 10mm wooden dowel of 125mm each.
Cut 1 piece 10mm wooden dowel of 304mm.
Print 2 of 3 way connector.stl
Print 1 of 4 way connector.stl
Print 3 of spool axle holder.stl
Print 4 of spool wheel.stl
Print 6 of spool frame clamps.stl
Mount the 284mm dowels to the 8mm rear upper and lower cross bars with the spool frame clamps and adjust them with a gap of 125mm between the dowels.
Fit a 125mm dowel between one 3 way connector and the 4 way connector and another 125mm dowel between the other side of the 4 way connector and the other 3 way connector so that one end of the connectors points toward the front of the machine and the other end down.
Fit this unit over the three uprights.
Fit a 125mm dowel into each of the connectors facing forward.
Fit a spool axle holder over the end of each of these three dowels with the open ends facing up.
Place a spool wheel into each side of your BFB filament spools and insert the 304mm dowel through their centers and push this assembly into the open ends of the spool axle holders.

title: Customizable Dial Indicator Mount for Stepstruder

description.text: Customizable dial indicator mount for the front of a stepstruder

The customizer defaults (and the .stl file) work with a Tekton brand dial indicator for sure, and I'm willing to bet most others too. Print.
Wait for printer to cool.
Remove the fan, heatsink, and spacers from the front of your stepstruder and bolt the indicator mount where they once were. Clamp your dial indicator in place using an M3 nut and bolt.
Lower your z axis until the indicator tip makes contact with your build platform. If your bot is sufficiently cool, turn it on, jog the platform around and see if it's level. (If it's not cool your fan is probably going to come on and cause some mayhem depending on where you placed it.) When you are done, reassemble your stepstruder and recalibrate.

Extruder case for the Bondtech drive gears. Unless you have a specific reason to use this version, most people will be better off using the design provided by Bondtech (http://www.bondtech.se/stl-files/). That one has been well tested and works.

This version was made to be smaller and without the groove mount so I could quickly switch between direct drive and bowden. I'm using the following linked parts for mounting in direct drive and bowden modes.

Should be printable without support if using the default part orientation. See instructions for more info.

Printer:
-- RigidBot

Filaments:
-- Hatchbox Transparent Red ABS
-- Colorfabb XT-CF20

The PTFE tubing should be run all the way up to the drive gear (see picture)

Uses an E3D Embedded Bowden Coupling if used as a bowden extruder. I used my printer to install the coupling:

  1. Remove the plastic part of the coupling
  2. Heat hotend to above glass transition temperature
  3. Place part under the print head, with the coupling centered under the nozzle.
  4. Lower the nozzle in 0.1mm increments until the coupling is flush with the case.

title: Rack for Raspberry Pi B+ / 2 with Hifiberry Amp+

description.text:
This is a pattern to make a rack capable of holding 5 Raspberry Pi type B+ or B 2 with a child card Hifiberry Amp + on each. An opening on the side allows access to the terminal blocks for power and audio cables, and a front opening provides access to the Ethernet ports. A compartment on the side can accommodate an ethernet switch.
The second model adds two additional locations because I needed 7 location, but my printer tray was too small.
See picture for more comprehension.

Full multiroom presentation available here (in french): http://www.maison-et-domotique.com/56929-realisation-de-multiroom-audio-a-base-de-raspberry-pi-hifiberry/
I generated gcode with Slic3r and all worked fine.

Based on the generic shape of Andrewar's c7 cover at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9719 this was designed and sized to fit on the common 12mm Pixels and dumb LED's used in many Christmas Light displays, and more specifically my display.

This cover is 55mm high and 24mm in diameter and is a firm fit on the pixel. Printed with 2 layers for strength, and additional support at the join of the base and light, this should last well outside for the Christmas display time here in Australia.

The demo was printed in White ABS, but the final versions will be printed in natural ABS, with a layer of Krylon clear UV protecting spraypaint to keep them looking fresh for a few years to come.

2 layer walls, 2 layer base and 3 layer top. 0.2mm layer height and 60mm/sec speed (But can go faster with no problems), 100% infill, but I think there is only 1 or 2 layers at the transition of base to lamp sides which are filled, and no supports needed at all.

Full writeup on my blog at: http://eclecti.cc/hardware/physical-keygen-duplicating-house-keys-on-a-3d-printer It occurred to me recently that I had printed almost nothing actually useful on my RepRap 3D printer, aside from parts to improve on or build more RepRaps. I am rectifying that with this project. The goal here is to generate working house keys by inputing the key code of the lock into a parametric OpenSCAD model. Instead of having to explain to my landlord how I ended up with a wedge of plastic jammed in my front door, I ordered a box of (well) used locks and latches from eBay to experiment on. Luckily, the lot includes both Kwikset KW1 and Schlage SC1 locks, which are the two most commonly found in the US. I created an SC1 model to start with, but Iâ€™ll probably make a KW1 soon. EDIT: I uploaded a KW1 model as well. Designing the key model was actually pretty straightforward. I measured a key with a ruler and calipers and created an approximate model of it that is reasonably easy to print. I then got pin depth specifications and parametrically differenced them out of the model. To generate new keys, you can just edit the last line of the file and enter in the key code for your key. If the code isnâ€™t written on the key, you can measure the height of each bit and compare to the numbers in the Root Depth column on the aforementioned pin depth site. Perhaps more nefariously, you could implement something like SNEAKEY to generate key codes without physically measuring the key.

Youâ€™ll of course need OpenSCAD to edit the .scad file and generate an STL to print out, unless your key just happens to be 33172 like the example STL posted below.  If it is, you can unlock the doorknob currently sitting on my desk.  As a small, precise object, this is a great test of how accurate your Skeinforge settings are.  You may need to adjust some thicknesses or the built in pin depth fudge factor to get it working properly with your printer.  The pictures above show the key being used on a disconnected lock cylinder, but I found it was also strong enough to turn a deadbolt.  If your lock needs a lot of force to turn, you may need to cut a space into the key to use a torsion wrench with it.

comments.text: I don't use OpenSCAD either but it was very easy to change the numbers to match my key. Download the file, open it in OpenSCAD and on the last line there is a group of numbers -- kw1([1,3,3,2,3]);. Change them to match your key and export the stl file. It's that easy. The hardest part will be determining which direction to read the pins. Just compare the exported file to the original key before printing and that problem is solved too.

title: Sound deverting human ear for tablets

description.text:
hello, this is my first thing!

My idea was the fact, that an human ear probably is the best shape for sound input. It has, after all, took millions of years to develop this thing. ok, if your an creationist, you don't believe that fact ;-)

so why the ear shape should not be good as an speaker. Moreover, my tablet only got one speaker on the back, which is often too quiet.

i am amazed at how well the new ear on my tablet works!

the tablet is definitely louder and looks fabulous in my opinion (if you like the natural style)!

PS: the original human ear is from tpower118, published Jun 19, 2013 on thingiverse (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:105808). hey tpower118, thanks for your work!

PS: this is also an entry on the 3d-printing contest on instructables: PLEASE VOTE!
http://www.instructables.com/contest/3dprintingcontestxxl/

i use PLA with the following printing settings:

Supports: yes
Raft: yes
Infill: 70% (less likely works as well)
Shells: 2

the other settings such as printing speed and layer thickness depends on the capabilities of your printer.

To remove the print from the printing plate* I take the good old carpenter chisel. this is definitely the best tool for doing this. the chisel is an good tool to remove the supports an clean the print too! make sure that the chisel is keen, otherwise you don't have fun with it.

title: Zeta FX-61 Phantom Wing Motor Mount

description.text:
The FX-61 wing comes with a very short motor mount which is not suitable for slim motors or bigger propellers.

This design is very stable and robust due to the large area and tough PLA material. The size of the mount allows for the ESC to be inside of it rather than near the other electronics. There are holes for the cables too.

This design was made with the beta version of the OnShape software. Due to this reason the motor attachment surface is circular and a bit off side. This does not affect the performance.

The mount provides a good tight fit. For a next iteration might be a good idea to add a millimeter of extra length and add some more space on the cables holes.

Note: If you are having trouble with one or more of the feet or trunk sliding off from their positions; try printing with elephant-raft.stl placed directly underneath the main model. This will trick the slicing software into building a single raft with the feet and trunk connected.

A remix of roman_hegglin's Voronoi Elephant model, modified to have a flatter base for more stable printing.

Originally the latest version of Makerbot Desktop (3.7.0.95) failed to create a raft under the trunk at all and created pin point sized rafts under the centre of each foot. With the underside of each foot and the trunk flattened the model slices correctly and prints with a stable base.

description.text:
Voici mon projet, j'ai réalisé un bateau qui associe, le design, la simplicité et surtout la rapidité.

J'ai commencé l'impression, pour les photos et les tests il faudra attendre encore un peu.

Je détaillerai plus tard tout ce qu'il faut pour le montage du moteur etc.... ainsi que la partie mécanique.

je mettrai des photos et des détails de tout pour que vous puissiez vous amusez.

En espérant qu'il vous plaira !!!!

Pour le moment les données sont provisoires, le projets ainsi que les conseils peuvent être modifiés quand j'aurais fait les tests.

Mise à jour 09-07-15, Socle gouvernail ainsi que le gourvernail complètement modifié pour une meilleur stabilité.

Mise à jour 10-07-15, caisson au niveau de l'hélice pour plus de propulsion.

L'impression de la coque avant, arrière, ainsi que les 2 parties du capot moteur et le socle avec le gouvernail, vous pouvez l'imprimé avec une densité de remplissage de 20 % avec un débit de 70% par contre pour l'hélice, l'imprimer avec une densité supérieur à 30% avec un débit à 100%

La vitesse moyenne d'impression pour la vertex k8400 est entre 150 et 200 mm/s sans problème, pour ma part impeccable.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
New Exoskeleton Legs & Feet >>> https://sellfy.com/p/F3n1/
New Exoskeleton Arms >>> https://sellfy.com/p/Zr0t/

Updated - (9th July 2015) - New predrilled holes for models

3D printed exoskeleton hands that I made for a bit of fun. If you want to watch a video of it in use https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=t7T-S3UFR-0. For the latest 3D printed exoskeleton updates visit https://sellfy.com/3DPrintIt. My website is http://3dprintit.com.au/.

DESCRIPTION

PLEASE READ THE MANUAL BEFORE PRINTING

The manual is in the .zip file. I designed the hand using ABS plastic the more infill the stronger the hand but the longer the print time. The entire hand will take approximately 18 hours in total and cost about $8.00 in plastic (at 4 cents a gram). All parts were printed on my Up Plus 2 with 14cm x 15cm x 15cm build volume. There are also a lot of metal screws that you need to hold all of the printed parts together. I used sheet metal self tapper pan screws 8G x 9mm.

***Disclaimer – 3D Print It will not be liable for personal injury resulting from negligent use of this product. Please use the 3D Printed Exoskeleton with care and do not cause harm to others. The purchasing of this product does not award the customer the rights to use this 3D model for monetary gain or re-sale. The designer retains all copyrights and intellectual property rights even after these files are sold. Do not distribute the 3D Printed Exoskeleton STL files. The files that you have bought are for your personal use only.

Copyright (c) Alex Czech 2015
Please read the 'Exoskeleton_Hands_Manual.pdf' and you'll be fine.

comments.author: mdj11211

comments.text:
To everyone wondering about different material! I printed this out of PLA and it worked fine. Most of the pieces fit securely without the screws but some where loose. My only problem was that my hand is a little smaller and so the base plate keeps sliding around. Other than that it the wrist pin was too big so I scaled it down by 3% and then it was flawless. Here are my print/printer settings
Printer: Monoprice Select mini
Infill: 50%
Infill pattern: tetrahedral
Print Temp: 220
Base Temp: 0
Base Plate Size: 120mm, 120mm, 120mm.
Diameter: 1.75
Support: true, everywhere
Speed: 65mm/s
Build plate adhesion: Raft
Raft top layer: 1
Overall print time: ~27-30 hours

comments.text: Seeing this brings tears to my eyes.  At the age of 4, in 2009, my son suffered a major open fracture of his humerus (upper arm bone) and lost all use of his arm.  There is a major nerve that wraps around the bone and it was significantly damaged during the injury.  While the bone and nerve were healing, the physical therapists wanted his hands (which were not receiving nerve communications) to be simulated and not atrophy in the absence of demands from the brain.  A brillant, local hand therapist created a device out of melt and mold plastic that let each of his fingers be suspended in rubber band swings so that any movement of his fingers (accidental or applied by us since his brain could not tell his hand to move) would have additional resistance.  We were trying to make any movement be a training exercise to keep his muscles limber during the months of inactivity.  What I see in this picture very much resembles that device.  This is not an ironman, look-alike toy - this is a miracle.  My son now has full use of his hand and arm and is competitive rock climber.  All because we had a creative tinkerer for a physical therapist.  3D printed versions of that concept as shown here could restore movement to countless injury victims - even if they don't have access to a brilliant local resource such as we stumbled upon.  The key is that resistance (bands) would need to be added so that it doesn't just act as an exoskeleton but acts as an exoskeleton with ligaments.
comments.author: LarchmontMakerMom

Initially I just it for a bit of fun but now I'm starting to realize some practical applications for it so thank you for posting such a wonderful comment. comments.text: If anyone is wondering what screws I used => Sheet metal self tapper pan screws 8G x 9mm. You could also use a 6G x 12mm. This is a 3-D printable case for the parallella 16-core Desktop Edition computer. The case allows for passive cooling, but be sure to install the required heatsink that comes with the Parallella before hand!

The two types of special connectors allow multiple units to be connected together to form a cluster.

We designed this case for use in my parallel computing class held in Spring 2015. All students in my parallel computing course used the case with their Parallella in the course. We have not encountered any issues with overheating.

Credits:
The case was co-designed by Suzanne J. Matthews and William ("Frank") Blackmon.

title: Z Probe removable module - for manual leveling E3D

description.text:
I don't like idea of calibrating leveling every time before printing.

  • Glass bed is usually very stable after one calibration
  • Auto correction takes controllers CPU time to correct Z values and decrease printing quality and speed.

My idea is to make perfect calibration once, with glass bed, fix it, and check its leveling after some time.

This module allows you to make level calibration as perfect as possible by using Bed height map option of Repetier-host.

Mount micro switch, without leaver, to this module and attach module to the hotend when you want to make calibration.
Connect switch to Zmin connection and modify firmware to enable Z probe.

I am using Repetier-firmware with RAMPS1.4 and Z probe is on pin 18.
Manual calibration can be achieved by modifying Tower X,Y,Z endstop offsets values in EPROM.
Just play little bit with values, and after every change re-test Bed height map. If you getting lower difference between lowest and highest value, you are on right path.
You do not need to change all tree offsets, just two of them.
Once you get difference about 0.1-0.2 between lowest and top values, consider leveling done.

Finally, I always confirm my level calibration with large test like this.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:702690

WARNING: Do NOT power hotend while module is still attached.

Module is optimized for E3Dv6 hotend.
It is 6mm below hotend nozzle.

For those who like Auto configuration, check my YT video and visit forum topic about
OpenDACT, http://forum.seemecnc.com/viewtopic.php?f=36&t=8698

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8Xt3Te73Xdo
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cQ1uTnZpUzM

description.text:
A small XY-moveable Scanner to create a (low detailed) 3D Picture of your environment.

Movement is done with 2x "Servo 9g".

The sensor is an "HC-SR04".

Next step will be to create the electronics and the display...

Edit: Added a very first picture of a scan. The scan is of course (like expected) low detailed, but you can see the shape of the bottle. I have some ideas to improve the quality, but for now I have to go on and do some other stuff. Maybe I will work again on it in some weeks.

Edit 2: Added the SourceCode for the ATMega8, which is sending the data to its UART with 250kbit/s, 8bit Data, no partity.
Additionally there is a "PHP" file which converts the LOG-Files to PNG.
PLEASE NOTE: This is only a quick and dirty hack, just to see if it the idea, that I had is realizable.

Edit 3: Source code also available here: https://github.com/PalArt/3D-Ultrasonic-Scanner

title: Replicator 2X Z-Axis Shims for Glass Plates

description.text:
Make your printer home it's z-axis a little lower so you can fit a glass plate on top of the build platform without the extruder nozzles crashing into the glass. Version 2

  • 2013-05-19
    Added 6mm and 9mm versions. I haven't tested or even printed these larger sizes but they'll probably work fine. If any of the sizes don't work for you just let me know and I'll see what I can do.

    • 2013-05-18
    I've made it much shorter and snugger and there's no more wiggle. It works the same way as before except now it only fits over the part of the board directly underneath the endstop switch. The shim is now 3.2mm high, which is somewhere between 1/8" and the actual thickness of my 1/8" glass plate. Version 1

  • I just sliced a little bit off the bottom of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:67494 to make it work with my 1/8th inch glass plate. I plan on making it a little snugger to reduce the wiggle. I also want to make it much shorter so that it's less likely to warp and so that any warping that does occur is less of an issue.

    • 1/8th inch is 3.175mm and this shim is only 2.5mm but there is more than enough action on the leveling screws to make up the difference.

Version 2

  • I tuned the design of the 3.2mm shim to my print settings and printed the STL file as-is on my 1/8" glass plate using a previous version of the shim that I haven't uploaded. I used Sailfish 7.4 firmware with MakerWare on High Quality (replicatorG and I aren't friends right now).

    • Infill: 15%
    Shells: 3
    Layer Height: 0.20mm Extruder Temp: 230C
    HBP Temp: 110C The shim is no longer centered on the device. It now sits to YOUR left of the z-axis drive-shaft, directly under the endstop switch. The little notch faces the back of the machine and will fit around a support on the backside of the board. Move the extruder carriage to the front the printer and lower the build plate so that you can easily reach behind the z-axis drive-shaft. Fit the notch in the back first, then roll the shim forward and press down. It's a tight fit but should click into place without too much forcing. To remove it pull up on the front and it should pop off. If it falls between the two boards you'll need to get a flashlight and fish it out. If it falls behind the rear board it might fall all the way down if you jog the plate up and down a little. In either case it's possible to get the shim jammed against the drive-shaft and potentially harm your machine so be careful if it falls in somewhere. Version 1

  • Printed at .20mm, 2 shells, 30% infill. I want it to be fairly rigid so that the z-axis returns to the exact same position every time, but my settings are probably overkill.

    • You don't have to remove the back of your machine. Just lower your build plate until you can easily reach behind the Z-axis rod and fit this over the back board of the z carriage (behind the piece with the M logo). The notch in the shim faces the rear of printer and should be centered right behind the rod.

description.text:
Who doesn't love Mortal Kombat?

Sculpted out a nice MK logo with Zbrush, but why stop there? I also cut the file into 16 part's to be printed and pieced together. Included the full version also. Print it out, Paint it up, hang it on your wall. It should be about 20x20 in or so when full sized, currently printing it myself now.

Please share if you make one! I'm not opposed to a tip as well! ;)

For the one piece print, download the MKsign.stl

To be a real man (or Woman) download the MK1-16.stl part's and print them out, seam them together with your preferred method (I use ABS and then use a ABS+Acetone mix to seam thing's together very nicely.) and paint it up, hang it up wherever, and be the envy of your entire town.

This is my own easy; print and glue, single shot loom/elastic band shooter! I printed mine at 200 microns at 15% infill.

No support structure required!

In the picture you can see four pink loom bands which gives the trigger tension, this is compulsory, just set them like I have in the picture. There is a knock at the end of the 'barrel', you pull the loom band from there, across the length of the gun and over the trigger. Then you are ready to fire!

Any upgrade suggestions greatly appreciated :)

title: Backlash Reducer for Overlord / Overlord Pro
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
UPDATED ALTERNATIVE VERSION AVAILABLE HERE: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1421326

This backlash reducer let you mount a spring or rubber band easily to the arm joints to reduce the backlash of the Dreammaker Overlord / Overlord Pro effector.

Print 12 of these (1 to start with to get your settings right), get some springs of appropriate size/force or rubber bands, and mount them over the joints.
Use at least 50% infill and shell thickness of at least 1,2 mm for a good result. Print it with support and with the flat surface down against the bed.

[Mounting Instructions] Place the spring/rubber band on one backlash reducer and attach/slide the part over the joint. Then put the spring on the other backlash reducer and pull it away to tense the spring and slide the over the other joint, this will be the easiest way to mount the part.

IMPORTANT [1]: Remote the dust filter of the fan cooling the hot end before mounting these backlash reducers! (Fan pulls air from the hotend so the filter is of no use anyway.)

IMPORTANT [2]: The Overlord 3D printer is currently not printing files to 100% 3D size. A firmware update from dreammaker is needed to correct this, but in the meanwhile this also means that you need to do a test print of the part, and if it does not fit correctly, either scale it up or down in your slicer until you get a good fit.

Edit 2015-06-22:
Decreased clearance for a more snug fit.
Remember to push the backlash reducer onto the joints!

Edit 2015-11-20:
Now after 5 months I one of the items snapped of, I do believe PLA turns brittle over time so if this happens to you, be sure to print it in ABS or PETG, that should help if you experience this issue; Or just print one or two in PLA again and replace, its most environmentally friendly after all.

comments.text: Whenever I try to print this with my Overlord pro (and with hatchbox black pla filament) the top portion always ends up as a globby mess. What can I do to my settings in Cura or on the printer itself to fix this?

I believe it may be cause of lack of proper cooling, try enabling cool head lift and set minimum layer time to 20 sec.

comments.text: I wish I had some putty to check and visualize the void. Truth be told, all 12 of mine scaled up 3% to adjust for my printers idiosyncrasies work fantastically. A buddy that printed out a couple couldn't get them to fit properly though.  They would rock somewhere around that conical feature and not fit cleanly.  Doesn't seem to be any flashing from supports, but hard to tell.
comments.author: Pawpawpaw85

comments.text:
There are some flaws on the Overlord that makes the results not quite consistent across printers (some have different length rods, some cant properly level their platform) and the auto-calibration is a bit flawed.
Your friends printer may differ enough on the output to not make it fit well. Maybe you can help him by printing one and see if it fits his joints?
Also, the X/Y scale on the printers are by default too small, mine was off by 2% before, but Z axis was fine, so one might have to make an non uniform scaling on the parts to get it properly output by the printer. Or you could alter the step/mm until they fix it in the firmware.
comments.author: bummster

comments.text: I'm still printing mine up, but they for sure don't look as nicely printed as yours!
comments.author: bummster

comments.text: If you're having problems printing them to fit (be sure to start with 1 to get your settings right) you can in the meanwhile attach springs or rubber bands with regular zip ties to the joints. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OermTZQGlao Thats what I started doing before creating this item. It does not work as well, but it might just be enough so that you can print these parts good enough to get them to fit over the joints.
comments.author: bummster

comments.text: I printed three with no tweaks only to find out that I was around 3% too small.  The end links have an outer diam of 10.44 or so on my crappy digital calipers, but the inner diameter of the first batch I printed were all around 10.1.  So, those got binned.  I scaled up your STL model to 1.03 and now get an inner diameter of ~10.5 or so. But, like I mentioned, mine look horrible.  They fit, but have loads of irregularities. Your initials are nearly indiscernible on my samples. The detail of the cavity under the hook is a mess. It's not a mess because of the supports, it's got schmoo that was pushed all over. Nothing a pair of hako snippers can't fix to make them fit.  Still tweaking and adjusting, I'll post a "made" once i get one i'm happy with.
comments.author: Pawpawpaw85

comments.text: You should really try to attach your rubber bands or springs with zipties or with tape, just something to stabilize the joints should help a great deal. And dont worry how they look, if it improves your printer, you can just print them again better :) (so little material it's almost without any cost).

description.text: I decided I to trash my LED strip @ http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8712 due to performance issues. Either I used an incorrect sized LED (unlikely as it was calculated for 10 LEDs) or the LEDs are of inferior quality as the brightness slowly started fading over the course of a few days. This past weekend I bought a 64 LED headlamp. It works on 3 x 1.5V AA batteries but I'll soon attach wires to the battery holder to power it from an alternative source. The forehead pad where the head strap also secures to is held to the light unit with 3 small screws. I designed the mounting to be screwed in it's place using the same screws. The light's base mounting can hinge vertically. The swivel mount attaches that in turn to the "frame mounting" and can turn horizontally. In my case I designed the frame mount to be mounted on the dowel uprights of my filament spool mount @ http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8924

title: Bicycle
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Bicycle printed on a UP! Mini.
It was intended as a trophy for being 12.5 years with the company.

I don't have a race bike nor intend to own one.
I took some information from the net about frames. From there I created a frame, the wheels and the rest. It came out that the front wheel should be smaller as the backwheel... so be it.

Known issues:
Play of the axles in their bearing could be reduced.
Play of the front fork in the frame is OK.
Play of the pedal-axle in the frame could be reduced.
To use an elastic band for a chain, carefully cut the right-rear leg from the frame, put the elastic band over the hubs, than glue it back in place.
The pedal-axles have a press fit into the kranks, holes in the kranks could be a bit larger.

Just printed it on a UP! Mini.
As the bike is made full scale, you'll need to scale it down.
I've printed it scale 0.15.
The shield was printed with "on the fly" filament change to get the text and logo in the correct colors.
